Additional XPath Data 2:
CALABRESE NATALINO
ko22
Traditional variety which was one of the first in making broccoli well known. After the main flower has appeared, numerous side shoots continue to form until autumn. Cultivation of broccoli is generally easier than for cauliflower.
Type: early summer and autumn

Additional XPath Data 2:
NEW
FIOLARO
ko68
Old and rare variety of collard greens from Italy, the leaves of which are strongly reminiscent of dandelions. The tender shoots taste nice both raw and cooked. The flavors tend towards being sweet and spicy rather than cabbage-like. Cultivate like conventional broccoli.
Type: autumn

Explanations
Bioverita: This variety is an organic, newly bred, variety. It has been cultivated from the very outset in organic conditions, to best adapt to organic cultivation. Varieties that carry the Bioverita label are reproducible and fertile, and aim to offer an alternative to hybrid-seeds to professional gardeners.
Additional XPath Data 2:
RASMUS KS
 ko20
Strong medium-growing broccoli with gray-green leaves. Solid, fine-grained, big flowering stems. Strong, non-woody stalk. After main harvest side shoots can be harvested as broccoli sprouts. Mild, fine aromatic taste.
Type: early summer and autumn

SPROUTING BROCCOLI
ko25
This variety has purple buds and tender stalks, which ripen at the end of winter when hardly any other fresh vegetables are around. New side shoots continue to form on purple sprouting broccoli, which can be harvested multiple times. Bred by Sativa.
Type: autumn
